required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The BreaD Study - Bio-availability of D2 Vitamin Present in Bread
clinical_study.official_title: Work Package 5: The Potential Advantages and Limitations of Use of Novel Food-based Solutions for Prevention of Vitamin D Deficiency. Food-based Solutions for Optimal Vitamin D Nutrition and Health Through the Life Cycle (ODIN)

brief_summary.textblock: Vitamin D3 is synthesized in skin exposed to ultraviolet-B-irradiation of sunlight. However, in Northern Europe, including Finland, exposure to sunlight is limited or non-existent in winter. Between November and March, dietary or supplementary vitamin D intake is essential to maintain adequate serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (S-25(OH)D) concentrations. There are only a few natural dietary sources of vitamin D. Fish and egg yolks contain significant amounts of vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol), and some wild mushrooms are a source of vitamin D2 (ergocalciferol). Thus, vitamin D fortification of certain foods has been accepted as one strategy to improve vitamin D status of these populations. Vitamin D3 is currently mostly used in fortified products in Europe, although the production of plant-derived vitamin D2 would be more cost-effective. Data on the impact of food-derived vitamin D2 on S-25(OH)D3 are limited. An important consideration is whether food-based sources of vitamin D2 are effective in raising S-25(OH)D or whether they have a negative impact on S-25(OH)D3. The investigators investigated the bioavailability of vitamin D2 from UVB-radiated baking yeast in bread in terms of efficacy of raising total S-25(OH)D) as well its possible effects on S-25(OH)D2, S-25(OH)D3, serum parathyroid hormone (S-PTH) and serum calcium concentrations compared with D2 and D3 supplementation in a randomized placebo-controlled trial in young healthy females during winter in Finland.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in total 25(OH)D concentration at 4 and 8 weeks
primary_outcome.description: The effect of vitamin D (as form of D3, D2 or D2-fortified bread )supplementation on the serum 25(OH)D concentration

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in serum PTH concentration at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The effect of vitamin D (as form of D3, D2 or D2-fortified bread )supplementation on the serum PTH concentration

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in serum calcium concentration at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The effect of vitamin D (as form of D3, D2 or D2-fortified bread )supplementation on the serum calcium concentration

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in 25(OH)D2 concentration at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The effect of vitamin D (as form of D3, D2 or D2-fortified bread )supplementation on the serum 25(OH)D2 concentration

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in 25(OH)D3 concentration at 4 and 8 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The effect of vitamin D (as form of D3, D2 or D2-fortified bread )supplementation on the serum 25(OH)D3 concentration

arm_group.description: Group 1: daily dose of regular bread (87 g/d) and placebo pill (0 µg of vitamin D/d) for 8 weeks
Group 2: daily dose of regular bread (87 g/d) and D2 supplement (25 µg of vitamin D2/d.) for 8 weeks
Group 3: daily dose of regular bread (87 g/d) and D3 supplement (25 µg of vitamin D3/d.) for 8 weeks
Group 4: D2 fortified bread containing 25 µg of vitamin D2/d (bread dose 87g/d) and placebo pill for 8 weeks

intervention.description: Experimental group 2: daily vitamin D2 supplement 25ug/d for 8 weeks
Experimental group 3: daily vitamin D3 supplement 25ug/d for 8 weeks
Experimental group 4: vitamin D2 fortified bread containing 25 µg of vitamin D2/d (bread dose 87g/d) and placebo pill for 8 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- good general health (no continuous medication),
- Caucasian origin,
- body mass index (BMI) <30 kg/m2
- age 20-40 years
Exclusion Criteria:
- diagnosed celiac disease or cereal allergy
- a vacation in a sunny place during the study or within the preceding 2 months
- regular use of vitamin D supplements >15 µg/d
- pregnancy or breastfeeding during the study

facility.name: Department of Food and Environmental Sciences, University of Helsinki
